steps.title: Select a variety of plants.
steps.content: Select a variety of plants. You can use any types of plants for a kokedama as long as they will fit comfortably in your home when hanging. The plants will eventually be hung from ceiling hooks using twine. Kokedama are traditionally made up of a variety of different plants, so invest in variety when building a kokedama. Stop by a greenhouse and pick up some potted plants to build your kokedama. You can also take in plants from outdoors if you garden.

steps.title: Remove the plant by its roots.
steps.content: Remove the plant by its roots. Whether you're using potted plants or outdoor plants for your kokedama, the first step is to remove the plants by their roots. Remove the plant from the pot or ground. Gently use your fingers to remove the soil from around the roots. For plants with very fine roots, rinse them in the sink to remove the soil. When bringing a plant in from outdoors, always check the leaves for bugs and other pests before bringing it inside.

steps.title: Mix your moss and bonsai soil.
steps.content: Mix your moss and bonsai soil. Take a plastic grocery bag and bucket. Put on some gloves. Use peat moss and bonsai soil for your kokedama. Using a 7:3 ratio of moss to soil, mix your moss and soil together until you have an even mixture. You need enough moss and soil to cover every plant's roots in a ball of soil and moss. The precise amounts will vary depending on how big of a garden you're making.

steps.title: Make a soil ball.
steps.content: Make a soil ball. Remove a chunk of soil and moss from the bucket or plastic bag. Use your hands to roll it into a thick, firm ball. Make a ball big enough to completely cover a plant's roots. When you're done, set the ball aside.

steps.title: Secure the plant's roots with moss.
steps.content: Secure the plant's roots with moss. Use sphagnum moss, which you can buy online or at a greenhouse. Wrap the moss around the plant's roots several times until the roots are covered completely. Then, wrap some twine around the plant's roots to secure them. The amount of moss you need will vary depending on how big your ball is.

steps.title: Sandwich the roots in your ball.
steps.content: Sandwich the roots in your ball. Break your ball in half. Sandwich your plant's roots around the ball of moss and soil. Then, pat the ball together again so it's firmly secured around the roots. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Cover your ball in sheep moss.
steps.content: Cover your ball in sheep moss. Wrap a layer of sheet moss around your ball. You can buy sheet moss at a greenhouse or online. Get a full layer of sheet moss surrounding the ball. [2] X Research source The amount of moss you need varies depending on the size of your ball.

steps.title: Use twine to secure the ball.
steps.content: Use twine to secure the ball. Wrap twine around the ball as needed to secure the sheet moss. Tightly circle the twine around the ball until everything holds together. You should be able to lift and move your ball without soil or moss spilling. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Attach a loop for hanging.
steps.content: Attach a loop for hanging. Take another piece of twine. Use a piece as big as you want considering where you're going to hang your kokedama. Tie both ends of the twine around the twine securing the plant. You should now have a plant on a string you can hang up. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Hang your plants.
steps.content: Hang your plants. Choose a spot in your home to hang your kokedama. Place your plants directly in front of a north facing window if possible. If you don't have a north facing window, hang the plants two to three feet from a south, west, or east facing window. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Mist your plants daily.
steps.content: Mist your plants daily. Each day, lightly mist your plants with tap water in a spray bottle. You can also place a tray of pebbles and water underneath the plants to add necessary humidity. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Water your plants regularly.
steps.content: Water your plants regularly. You water kokedama plants by soaking them in a bowl of room temperature water for 10 minutes. Drain the soil ball in a colander until it stops dripping and then rehang the plants. [7] X Research source Kokedama plants should be watered when they start to feel light and the leaves turn brown.

steps.title: Trim dead leaves regularly.
steps.content: Trim dead leaves regularly. Watch your plants closely. When you notice any dead or brown leaves, use a pair of scissors or plant sheers to remove them. [8] X Research source Brown leaves that appear regularly are a sign you're not watering your plants often enough.

steps.title: Repot as your plants grow.
steps.content: Repot as your plants grow. As the plants grow, the roots will begin poking through the moss and soil balls. At this point, you need to repot them with new balls. For most plants, this is necessary about once or twice a year. [9] X Research source
